thread.title: Theresa May's cabinet are in the North East - but how Northern are they?

author: Sean Seddon
title: Theresa May's cabinet are in the North East - but how Northern are they?
text:
Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing!
Theresa May has brought her cabinet to the North East for a little outing - but do they really have any Northern credentials?
Monday’s visit by the Prime Minister and her team is supposed to tie in with the Great Exhibition of the North, a summer-long celebration of what the region has to offer.
But it’s fair to say England’s upper reaches aren’t particularly well represented around the cabinet table.
Of the 29 ministers attending cabinet, just two were born in the region and only five represent constituencies in the North. Prime Minister Theresa May (Image: Getty Images Europe)
The only MP with an immediate link to the North East is Greg Clark, the business secretary, who was born in Middlesbrough.
After that, the closest is Gavin Williamson, the defence secretary, who was born in Scarbrough.
Home Secretary Sajid Javid, Health Secretary Matthew Hancock and Secretary of State for Work and Pension Esther McVery were born in Rochdale, Chester and Liverpool respectively.
Of the constituencies represented by those in the cabinet, the nearest to the North East is Skipton and Ripon. Business Secretary Greg Clark (Image: Getty Images Europe)
That’s held by chief whip Julian Smith who, at time of writing, is still in a job but has faced calls to resign in recent days. Read More This is what to expect when Theresa May brings her Cabinet to the North East on Monday
He’s been embroiled in controversy over whether or not he told another minister to vote in a crunch Brexit vote, despite the fact an agreement was in place for him to abstain and balance out new-mum Jo Swinson’s absence.
The only other is Esther McVey’s seat, Tatton in Cheshire, which she won after George Osborne resigned to become editor of the London Evening Standard. Home Secretary Sajid Javid (Image: PA)
In terms of the very top level of Government , Home Secretary Sajid Javid is the only one with any link to the region and the rest are dominated by the South.
Every other holder of a ‘great office of state’ - the Prime Minister, the Foreign Secretary and the Chancellor - represents a seat in the home counties.
Four cabinet ministers hail from further north: Liam Fox, Michael Gove, David Mundell and Julian Smith were all born in Scotland. Read More Parliamentary logjam could derail North of Tyne devolution, Newcastle leader warns
Michael Gove spent some time living in Newcastle when he was training to be a journalist on a course based in Thomson House, the same building which used to house The Chronicle, The Journal and The Sunday Sun.
But beyond that tenuous link, few cabinet ministers will be heading ‘home’ when they visit the North East today. Like us on Facebook
